THEATER 10.description: Lecture, three hours; discussion, one hour (when scheduled). Exploration of theater in production, with emphasis on collaborative role of theater artists and active role of audience. Understanding of and access to live theatrical event and enhanced appreciation of value of theater to society; development of critical skills through consideration of representative examples of theatrical production from Europe, America, Asia, and Africa. P/NP or Letter grading.
THEATER 10.title: Introduction to Theater

THEATER 101A.description: Lecture, four hours; discussion, one hour. Examination of traditional performance traditions in terms of how they were produced, including training techniques, archive practices, and forms of history. Examples may include classical Greek tragedy, Noh and Kyogen, Za ju and Chuanqi, Quem Queritis/English medieval festival plays, Sanskrit drama, Yoruba/Egungun, Yaqui deer dance, depending on faculty and resources available. Letter grading.
THEATER 101A.title: Making Tradition

THEATER 101B.description: Lecture, three hours; discussion, one hour. Reconstructing theater is understood in several ways: reconstruction of performance spaces such as New Globe and of specific productions and traditions such as neoclassicism that seek to reinstate classical traditions. Letter grading.
THEATER 101B.title: Reconstructing Theatrical Past

THEATER 101C.description: Lecture, three hours; discussion, one hour. Exploration of deconstructive practices such as fragmentation, abstraction, and absurdism, with focus on theatrical movements, directorial adaptations, cultural translations, and new forms. Letter grading.
THEATER 101C.title: Deconstructing Theater

THEATER 102A.description: Lecture, three hours. Exploration of major theater traditions of Japan from emergence of earliest theatrical activity to present, including investigation of Noh, Bunraku, and Kabuki performance traditions. Letter grading.
THEATER 102A.title: Theater of Japan

THEATER 102B.description: Lecture, three hours. Examination of representative theatrical genre from various geographical areas in Southeast Asia to illustrate importance and contribution that theater plays in society. Letter grading.
THEATER 102B.title: Theater of Southeast Asia

THEATER 102C.description: Lecture, three hours. Exploration of interculturalism in theater, with focus on 20th-century alternatives to naturalism. Analysis of historical materials and dramatic texts to investigate cultural, aesthetic, ethical, and social implications of borrowing from other cultures. Letter grading.
THEATER 102C.title: Cross-Cultural Currents in Theater

THEATER 103F.description: Lecture, three hours. Study of American Indian theater as evolving art form. P/NP or letter grading.
THEATER 103F.title: Native American Theater

THEATER 103I.description: Lecture, three hours. No background on or prior interest in history or region or arts required. Land variously known by names of Zion, Holy Land, Palestine, and Israel is not just one place. It is a realm of imagination, envisioned and re-envisioned throughout history. It is at once real and surreal, sturdy and fragile, all-enduring and ephemeral. Examination of selected works of literature, performance, visual arts, film, and media by Israeli and Palestinian artists, as well as Western artists with interest in region. Looking beyond headlines and facile cultural clichés for deeper insights arts can offer into cultural conflict and community at large, to emerge with surprising conclusions. Letter grading.
THEATER 103I.title: Israel and Palestine: Communities, Conflicts, Cultures, and Arts in Middle East

THEATER 104D.description: Seminar, three hours. Required for students in playwriting sequence. How to approach diverse range of new plays currently changing landscape of theater. Contemporary look at plays written in last 15 years and how they reflect society. Reading of plays to build skills of manuscript analysis; development of working vocabulary of dramaturgical concepts; exploration of different styles of acting, directing, and design that playwrights of today draw from. Letter grading.
THEATER 104D.title: New Playwrights, New Playwriting

THEATER 105.description: Lecture, three hours. Critical examination of leading theories of theater from 1887 to present. Study and discussion of modern styles of production. P/NP or letter grading.
THEATER 105.title: Main Currents in Theater

THEATER 106.description: Lecture, four hours; discussion, one hour (when scheduled). Survey of key works of American dramatic literature and landmarks of American theater history. P/NP or Letter grading.
THEATER 106.title: History of American Theater and Drama

THEATER 107.description: Lecture, three hours; discussion, one hour (when scheduled). Investigation of diversity in American society as manifested in dramatic works and theatrical presentations. P/NP or Letter grading.
THEATER 107.title: Drama of Diversity

THEATER 108.description: Seminar, four hours. Limited to 15 students. Selected topics in history and criticism of theater and performance. Study of how experimental theaters originate, how they imagine their form of performance, their audience, and their goals. Concentration on theaters that regarded themselves, in some way, as experimental. Examples primarily from theaters within U.S. from 1960s to present, although examples from other countries, specifically Poland, also considered. Letter grading.
THEATER 108.title: Undergraduate Seminar: History and Criticism

THEATER 11.description: Seminar, four hours. Introduction to basic methods of interpretation in theater and performance throughout world. Topics illustrated by faculty members and guest speakers, visits to off-campus theaters, and reading from contemporary plays. Letter grading.
THEATER 11.title: Approaches to Interpretation of Theater and Performance: Global Perspective (Effective Spring 2018 )

THEATER 110.description: Lecture, three hours. Survey of history of American musical: its composers, writers, and performers from musical's emergence in immigrant cultures to Broadway and Off-Broadway. With its roots in British music halls and comic opera, Viennese operetta and African American jazz, American musical theater emerged as vivid and popular art form with its own culture and identity. P/NP or letter grading.
THEATER 110.title: History of American Musical Theater

THEATER 113.description: Lecture, three or four hours. Consult "Schedule of Classes" for author, period, genre, or subject to be studied in specific term. May be repeated for credit. P/NP or letter grading.
THEATER 113.title: Special Topics in Critical Studies

THEATER 115A.description: Studio, six hours. Introduction to physical approaches of actor training, with emphasis on development of ensemble skills, physical presence, and capacity to respond in moment to physical, special, textual, and subtextual stimuli. Letter grading.
THEATER 115A.title: Physical Systems of Acting: Foundations

THEATER 115B.description: Studio, six hours. Performance of original studies in physical theater and/or material from physical theater repertory. Course activities, materials, and discussions based on contemporary physical theater practices. Letter grading.
THEATER 115B.title: Physical Systems of Acting: Practice

THEATER 116A.description: Studio, six hours. Development of acting skills through sense memory, personalization, action, and objective exercises. Letter grading.
THEATER 116A.title: Psychological Systems of Acting: Foundations

THEATER 116B.description: Studio, six hours. Requisite: course 116A. Continuation of course 116A. Examination of characterization exercises and their application to contemporary scenes. Letter grading.
THEATER 116B.title: Psychological Systems of Acting: Practice (Effective Spring 2018 )

THEATER 118A.description: Lecture/laboratory, four hours. Studies of principles and procedures of improvisational approach to drama as done with children from nursery school to junior high. P/NP or letter grading.
THEATER 118A.title: Creative Dramatics

THEATER 118B.description: Lecture, four hours; other, to be arranged. Practical application of creative drama process. Exploration of interrelationships of arts to traditional disciplines of learning. May be repeated once for credit. P/NP or letter grading.
THEATER 118B.title: Advanced Creative Dramatics

THEATER 118C.description: Laboratory, four hours. Active, problem-solving process of theater exercises and games designed to examine racial stereotypes, sexual harassment, gender discrimination, and other issues that divide members of campus community, as well as issues that divide campus from Los Angeles community. Selected to increase social and political awareness of problems and ideas fundamental to intellectual development, exercises and games nurture skills and attitudes useful in facilitating discussions between actors and audience participants. Use of techniques of sensory awareness, movement, pantomime, improvisation, and characterization. Letter grading.
THEATER 118C.title: Interactive Theater

THEATER 118D.description: Lecture, four hours. Requisites: courses 118A, 118B. Development of K-12 teaching materials to integrate theater with specific core curricula. Collaboration with classroom teacher to identify core subject to be taught. Language arts, science, history, mathematics, and social sciences are possible curricular areas. Development of evaluation tools to measure effectiveness of incorporating theater materials into curriculum. Weekly meetings to discuss teaching strategies and prepare written lesson plans that incorporate California Teaching Content Standards, objectives, motivation, detailed implementation of lesson plan, and ideas for assessment. Classroom work culminates in thoroughly documented final project evaluated by ArtsBridge student, classroom teacher, and UCLA faculty members. P/NP or letter grading.
THEATER 118D.title: ArtsBridge Teaching Practicum

THEATER 12.description: Lecture, two hours; studio, four hours. Investigation of phenomenon of performance and role of performer in theatrical events, including interpretation of drama through performance. Examination of various forms of theatrical performance and styles of expression, and development of acting, voice, and movement skills. Letter grading.
THEATER 12.title: Introduction to Performance

THEATER 120A.description: Lecture, six hours. Exploration of acting and performance in film. Through screenings of performance-driven films, class discussion, and acting exercises, examination of methods, styles, and performances of some of world's most highly regarded actors and their work. P/NP or letter grading.
THEATER 120A.title: Acting and Performance in Film

THEATER 120B.description: Lecture, six hours. Exploration of acting and performance in film. Through screenings of performance-driven films, class discussion, and acting exercises, examination of methods, styles, and performances of some of world's most highly regarded actors and their work. P/NP or letter grading.
THEATER 120B.title: Acting and Performance in Film

THEATER 120C.description: Lecture, six hours. Exploration of acting and performance in film. Through screenings of performance-driven films, class discussion, and acting exercises, examination of methods, styles, and performances of some of world's most highly regarded actors and their work. Letter grading.
THEATER 120C.title: Acting and Performance in Film

THEATER 121.description: Studio, to be arranged. Requisite: course 20. Courses 160, 163A, 163B, and 163C may be taken concurrently. Workshop that provides students with opportunity to rehearse, perform, and criticize scenes. May be repeated once for credit. P/NP or letter grading.
THEATER 121.title: Acting Workshop

THEATER 123.description: Lecture/studio, four hours. Requisite: course 20. Study and practice of art of acting through perfecting of techniques and application of those techniques to acting problems. P/NP or letter grading.
THEATER 123.title: Intermediate Acting for Stage

THEATER 124A.description: Studio, three to four hours. Development of voice and speech techniques for stage. Letter grading.
THEATER 124A.title: Voice and Speech II

THEATER 124B.description: Studio, three to four hours. Development of voice and speech techniques for stage. Letter grading.
THEATER 124B.title: Voice and Speech II

THEATER 124C.description: Studio, three to four hours. Development of voice and speech techniques for stage. Letter grading.
THEATER 124C.title: Voice and Speech II

THEATER 124D.description: Studio, three to four hours. Development of voice and speech techniques for stage. Letter grading.
THEATER 124D.title: Voice and Speech III

THEATER 124E.description: Studio, three to four hours. Development of voice and speech techniques for stage. Letter grading.
THEATER 124E.title: Voice and Speech III

THEATER 124F.description: Studio, three to four hours. Development of voice and speech techniques for stage. Letter grading.
THEATER 124F.title: Voice and Speech III

THEATER 125A.description: Studio, three to four hours. Physical awareness for actors, concentrating on warming up body, relaxation, control, stunts, gymnastics, martial arts, and use of weapons. Letter grading.
THEATER 125A.title: Movement and Combat II

THEATER 125B.description: Studio, three to four hours. Physical awareness for actors, concentrating on warming up body, relaxation, control, stunts, gymnastics, martial arts, and use of weapons. Letter grading.
THEATER 125B.title: Movement and Combat II

THEATER 125C.description: Studio, three to four hours. Physical awareness for actors, concentrating on warming up body, relaxation, control, stunts, gymnastics, martial arts, and use of weapons. Letter grading.
THEATER 125C.title: Movement and Combat II

THEATER 125D.description: Studio, three to four hours. Physical awareness for actors, concentrating on warming up body, relaxation, control, stunts, gymnastics, martial arts, and use of weapons. Letter grading.
THEATER 125D.title: Movement and Combat III

THEATER 125E.description: Studio, three to four hours. Physical awareness for actors, concentrating on warming up body, relaxation, control, stunts, gymnastics, martial arts, and use of weapons. Letter grading.
THEATER 125E.title: Movement and Combat III

THEATER 125F.description: Studio, three to four hours. Physical awareness for actors, concentrating on warming up body, relaxation, control, stunts, gymnastics, martial arts, and use of weapons. Letter grading.
THEATER 125F.title: Movement and Combat III

THEATER 126A.description: Studio, six hours. Requisite: course 116B. Study of characterization, including introduction to Shakespeare. Approach to verse, scansion, use of embolies in classic texts. Personalization within heightened reality. Letter grading.
THEATER 126A.title: Acting III (Effective Spring 2018 )

THEATER 126B.description: Studio, six hours. Study of characterization, including introduction to Shakespeare. Approach to verse, scansion, use of embolies in classic texts. Personalization within heightened reality. Letter grading.
THEATER 126B.title: Acting III

THEATER 126C.description: Studio, six hours. Study of characterization, including introduction to Shakespeare. Approach to verse, scansion, use of embolies in classic texts. Personalization within heightened reality. Letter grading.
THEATER 126C.title: Acting III

THEATER 127A.description: Studio, six hours. Requisites: courses 126A, 126B, 126C. Comedy workshop, stand-up comedy, performance art pieces. Audition and cold reading workshop. Solving individual acting projects. Letter grading.
THEATER 127A.title: Advanced Acting

THEATER 127B.description: Studio, six hours. Requisites: courses 126A, 126B, 126C. Comedy workshop, stand-up comedy, performance art pieces. Audition and cold reading workshop. Solving individual acting projects. Letter grading.
THEATER 127B.title: Advanced Acting

THEATER 127C.description: Studio, six hours. Requisites: courses 126A, 126B, 126C. Comedy workshop, stand-up comedy, performance art pieces. Audition and cold reading workshop. Solving individual acting projects. Letter grading.
THEATER 127C.title: Advanced Acting

THEATER 128A.description: Studio, four to six hours. Study of advanced acting technique, scene study, and development of voice and movement skills. May be repeated for maximum of 12 units. Letter grading.
THEATER 128A.title: Acting, Voice, and Movement Workshop II

THEATER 13.description: Lecture, three hours. Provides base for subsequent study in theater. Development of techniques of play reading and habits of scholarship useful to further study in each of theater's subdisciplines, including acting, directing, design, playwriting, and critical study. Letter grading.
THEATER 13.title: Play Reading and Analysis

THEATER 130A.description: Studio, three hours. Designed for departmental majors and minors. Exploration of writing for live performance. Students develop and workshop short plays. May be repeated once for credit. Letter grading.
THEATER 130A.title: Fundamentals of Playwriting I

THEATER 130B.description: Lecture, three hours plus conference. Requisite: course 130A. Study in original material for theater, its preparation and development. Designed to give further insight into critical and creating aspects of short and full-length plays and guidance in completion of one-act and full-length plays. May be repeated twice for credit. P/NP or letter grading.
THEATER 130B.title: Fundamentals of Playwriting II

THEATER 130C.description: Lecture/laboratory, three hours. Study of practice and techniques used in writing libretto for musical theater: opening numbers, romance, subplots, and comedy. May be repeated once for credit. P/NP or letter grading.
THEATER 130C.title: Writing for American Musical Theater

THEATER 131A.description: Studio, three hours. Requisite: course 130A. Introduction to process of conceiving, researching, and developing full-length plays. Students begin drafting full-length plays. May be repeated twice for credit. Letter grading.
THEATER 131A.title: Intermediate Playwriting: Full-Length Play Part I

THEATER 131B.description: Studio, three hours. Requisite: course 131A. Continuation of writing of full-length plays begun in course 131A. May be repeated twice for credit. Letter grading.
THEATER 131B.title: Intermediate Playwriting: Full-Length Play Part II

THEATER 131C.description: Studio, three hours. Requisite: course 131A. Limited to juniors/seniors. Same as course 131B, but taken for capstone credit. Completion of writing of full-length plays begun in course 131A, with rehearsed readings of student capstone plays. Letter grading.
THEATER 131C.title: Playwriting: Full-Length Play Capstone

THEATER 132.description: Lecture, three hours. Requisite: course 130A. Principles and practices in evaluation of manuscripts for theater. May be repeated once for credit. P/NP or letter grading.
THEATER 132.title: Manuscript Evaluation for Theater

THEATER 134A.description: Studio, five hours. Designed for Theater majors. Development of dance and movement techniques for musical theater. Letter grading.
THEATER 134A.title: Dance for Musical Theater II

THEATER 134B.description: Studio, five hours. Designed for Theater majors. Development of dance and movement techniques for musical theater. Letter grading.
THEATER 134B.title: Dance for Musical Theater II

THEATER 134C.description: Studio, five hours. Designed for Theater majors. Development of dance and movement techniques for musical theater. Letter grading.
THEATER 134C.title: Dance for Musical Theater II

THEATER 134D.description: Studio, five hours. Designed for Theater majors. Development of dance and movement techniques for musical theater. Letter grading.
THEATER 134D.title: Dance for Musical Theater III

THEATER 134E.description: Studio, five hours. Designed for Theater majors. Development of dance and movement techniques for musical theater. Letter grading.
THEATER 134E.title: Dance for Musical Theater III

THEATER 134F.description: Studio, five hours. Designed for Theater majors. Development of dance and movement techniques for musical theater. Letter grading.
THEATER 134F.title: Dance for Musical Theater III

THEATER 134G.description: Studio, three to four hours. Designed for Theater majors. Intermediate level course. Development of skills and furthering of concepts of ballet technique. Emphasis on development of proper placement, building strength and flexibility, higher level of techniques, and awareness of musicality and artistic expression. May be repeated five times for credit. Letter grading.
THEATER 134G.title: Dance for Musical Theater: Ballet

THEATER 135A.description: Studio, five hours. Designed for Theater majors. Exploration of vocal styles and development of singing techniques for musical theater. Letter grading.
THEATER 135A.title: Singing for Musical Theater II

THEATER 135B.description: Studio, five hours. Designed for Theater majors. Exploration of vocal styles and development of singing techniques for musical theater. Letter grading.
THEATER 135B.title: Singing for Musical Theater II

THEATER 135C.description: Studio, five hours. Designed for Theater majors. Exploration of vocal styles and development of singing techniques for musical theater. Letter grading.
THEATER 135C.title: Singing for Musical Theater II

THEATER 135D.description: Studio, five hours. Designed for Theater majors. Exploration of vocal styles and development of singing techniques for musical theater. Letter grading.
THEATER 135D.title: Singing for Musical Theater III

THEATER 135E.description: Studio, five hours. Designed for Theater majors. Exploration of vocal styles and development of singing techniques for musical theater. Letter grading.
THEATER 135E.title: Singing for Musical Theater III

THEATER 135F.description: Studio, one hour. Designed to advance proper vocal technique, focusing on breadth support, vowel shape, range expression, and overall mastery of vocal instrument. May be repeated four times for credit. Letter grading.
THEATER 135F.title: Singing: Individual Instruction

THEATER 136.description: Studio, four hours. Requisite: course 123. Study and practice of art of acting through progression to more advanced acting problems. May be repeated twice for credit. Consecutive enrollment with same instructor not permitted. Total units for courses 136, 137A, 137B, and 137C may not exceed 12 units. Letter grading.
THEATER 136.title: Advanced Acting for Stage

THEATER 138.description: Studio, four hours. Study of complex problems in voice, movement, and acting. May be repeated twice for credit. P/NP or letter grading.
THEATER 138.title: Special Problems in Performance Techniques

THEATER 139.description: Lecture, three hours. Investigation of dramatic texts, with focus on play structure, plot, character, dialog, ideas, and various other elements essential to effective theatrical interpretation and realization. Letter grading.
THEATER 139.title: Play Reading and Analysis

THEATER 147A.description: Studio, four hours. Development of visual communication skills through drafting. Exploration of drafting for scenic and lighting designs. May be repeated once for credit. Letter grading.
THEATER 147A.title: Drafting

THEATER 147B.description: Studio, four hours. Introductory course in basic skills necessary for drawing, by hand, scenic design for theater. Letter grading.
THEATER 147B.title: Drawing Scenery

THEATER 148.description: Lecture, three hours. Group study of selected subjects in design and technical theater. May be repeated twice for credit. P/NP or letter grading.
THEATER 148.title: Special Courses in Design and Technical Theater

THEATER 149.description: Lecture, three hours. Exploration of interpretation of drama through design, including study of styles and techniques of design, collaborative role of designer, principles of design for scenery, lighting, costumes, and sound. Both technical and aesthetic groundwork for further study. Investigation of techniques for realization of designs in production. Letter grading.
THEATER 149.title: Introduction to Design

THEATER 14A.description: Lecture, three hours; studio, six hours. Exploration of visual interpretation of drama. Study of styles and techniques of design, collaborative role of designer, principles of design for scenery, lighting, costumes, and sound. Both technical and aesthetic groundwork for further study. Letter grading.
THEATER 14A.title: Introduction to Design

THEATER 14B.description: Lecture, three hours; studio, six hours. Exploration of visual interpretation of drama. Study of styles and techniques of design, collaborative role of designer, principles of design for scenery, lighting, costumes, and sound. Both technical and aesthetic groundwork for further study. Letter grading.
THEATER 14B.title: Introduction to Design

THEATER 14C.description: Lecture, three hours; studio, six hours. Exploration of visual interpretation of drama. Study of styles and techniques of design, collaborative role of designer, principles of design for scenery, lighting, costumes, and sound. Both technical and aesthetic groundwork for further study. Letter grading.
THEATER 14C.title: Introduction to Design

THEATER 15.description: Lecture, two hours; studio, four hours. Investigation of role of director in theatrical production and theories of play direction, with emphasis on analysis and interpretation of dramatic work and its realization in production. Letter grading.
THEATER 15.title: Introduction to Directing

THEATER 150.description: Laboratory, three to six hours. Laboratory experience in various aspects of theater production, including performance in project or production, stage management, member of crew, or assignment as designer or assistant on production. May be repeated for maximum of 8 units. Letter grading.
THEATER 150.title: Theater Production and Performance

THEATER 159.description: Lecture/studio, four hours. Requisites: courses 14A, 14B, 14C. Preparation of complete designs and drawings for production and assembly of design portfolio and résumé. Projects prepared under guidance of faculty adviser. Letter grading.
THEATER 159.title: Design Portfolio Project

THEATER 160.description: Lecture, two hours; laboratory, four hours. Course 121 may be taken concurrently. Basic theories of play direction and their application through preparation of scenes under rehearsal conditions. P/NP or letter grading.
THEATER 160.title: Fundamentals of Play Direction

THEATER 163A.description: Lecture/studio, four hours. Requisite: course 15. Intensive development of primary directing skills and process, including text analysis and exploration of craft fundamentals as basis for director/actor communication and effective staging. Students direct scenes from plays under laboratory conditions. Letter grading.
THEATER 163A.title: Directing for Stage

THEATER 163B.description: Lecture/studio, four hours. Requisite: course 15. Further development of craft elements of directorial method, with additional emphasis on psychological aspects of director/actor communication. Students direct scenes under laboratory conditions in alternative stage configurations. Letter grading.
THEATER 163B.title: Directing for Stage

THEATER 163C.description: Lecture/studio, four hours. Requisite: course 15. Culminating development of directorial methods, with particular emphasis on challenges of style in text and production. Students direct scenes under laboratory conditions in alternative stage configurations. Letter grading.
THEATER 163C.title: Directing for Stage

THEATER 170.description: Laboratory, eight hours. Requisites: courses 14A, 14B, 14C. Experience as stage manager or designer, including participation in preparation and realization of scenic, lighting, costume, or sound designs, or stage management in production. May be repeated once for credit. Letter grading.
THEATER 170.title: Design and Production Project

THEATER 171A.description: Laboratory, to be arranged. Creative participation as actor or stage manager in public presentation of departmental productions. May be taken for maximum of 4 units. P/NP or letter grading.
THEATER 171A.title: Advanced Theater Laboratory

THEATER 171B.description: Laboratory, to be arranged. Creative participation in realization of production elements related to public presentation of departmental productions. May be taken for maximum of 4 units. P/NP or letter grading.
THEATER 171B.title: Advanced Theater Laboratory

THEATER 172.description: Studio, three to eight hours. Exploration and laboratory experience in one or more various aspects of production and postproduction practice for entertainment media, including theater, film, video, and digital media. May be repeated for maximum of 24 units. Letter grading.
THEATER 172.title: Production Practice in Theater, Film, Video, and Digital Media

THEATER 173A.description: Studio, six hours. Requisites: courses 14A, 14B, 14C. Laboratory experience as assistant designer, including participation in preparation and realization of scenic, lighting, costume, or sound designs. May be repeated twice. Letter grading.
THEATER 173A.title: Design Assignment: Assistant Designer

THEATER 173B.description: Studio, six hours. Requisites: courses 14A, 14B, 14C. Laboratory experience as designer, including preparation and realization of scenic, lighting, costume, or sound designs. May be repeated twice. Letter grading.
THEATER 173B.title: Production Design Assignment: Designer

THEATER 174A.description: Studio, six hours. Requisites: courses 14A, 14B, 14C. Professional duties of stage manager. Problems of unions, professional auditions, organization, scheduling, out-of-town openings, Broadway openings, and responsibilities of lengthy run. Letter grading.
THEATER 174A.title: Stage Managing Techniques

THEATER 174B.description: Studio, nine hours. Requisite: course 174A. Laboratory experience in professional duties of assistant stage manager, including participation as assistant stage manager in preproduction, rehearsal, and performance phases of productions. May be repeated once for credit. Letter grading.
THEATER 174B.title: Project in Stage Management

THEATER 174C.description: Studio, 12 hours. Requisite: course 174A. Laboratory experience in professional duties of stage manager, including participation as stage manager in preproduction, rehearsal, and performance phases of productions. Problems of unions, auditions, organization, scheduling, and responsibilities of lengthy run. May be repeated three times for credit. Letter grading.
THEATER 174C.title: Project in Stage Management

THEATER 174D.description: Lecture, two hours; studio, two hours. Requisites: courses 147A, 174A. Professional duties of stage management. Practical training, including paper techniques, dry techniques, cue 2 cue, preshow setup, performance reports, and quick change rehearsals. Letter grading.
THEATER 174D.title: Advanced Stage Management Techniques

THEATER 175A.description: Laboratory, 12 to 24 hours. Participation in various aspects of theater production and performance. Offered in summer only. Letter grading.
THEATER 175A.title: Summer Theater Workshop

THEATER 175B.description: Laboratory, three hours. Participation in various aspects of theater production and performance. Offered in summer only. Letter grading.
THEATER 175B.title: Summer Theater Workshop

THEATER 175C.description: Laboratory, 12 to 24 hours. Participation in various aspects of theater production and performance. Offered in summer only. Letter grading.
THEATER 175C.title: Summer Theater Workshop

THEATER 175D.description: Laboratory, 12 to 24 hours. Participation in various aspects of theater production and performance. Offered in summer only. Letter grading.
THEATER 175D.title: Summer Theater Workshop

THEATER 180.description: Lecture or studio, three hours. Requisites: courses 101A, 101B, 101C. Preparation of conceptual or creative project to provide culminating experience in production of creative or research work. May be repeated twice for credit. Letter grading.
THEATER 180.title: Senior Project

THEATER 181.description: Lecture, three hours; fieldwork, three hours. Limited to seniors. Study of business practices, career entry, and development for actors. P/NP or letter grading.
THEATER 181.title: Career Development for Actors

THEATER 188SA.description: Tutorial, to be arranged. Enforced corequisite: Honors Collegium 101E. Limited to junior/senior USIE facilitators. Individual study in regularly scheduled meetings with faculty mentor to discuss selected USIE seminar topic, conduct preparatory research, and begin preparation of syllabus. Individual contract with faculty mentor required. May not be repeated. Letter grading.
THEATER 188SA.title: Individual Studies for USIE Facilitators

THEATER 188SB.description: Tutorial, to be arranged. Enforced requisite: course 188SA. Enforced corequisite: Honors Collegium 101E. Limited to junior/senior USIE facilitators. Individual study in regularly scheduled meetings with faculty mentor to finalize course syllabus. Individual contract with faculty mentor required. May not be repeated. Letter grading.
THEATER 188SB.title: Individual Studies for USIE Facilitators

THEATER 188SC.description: Tutorial, to be arranged. Enforced requisite: course 188SB. Limited to junior/senior USIE facilitators. Individual study in regularly scheduled meetings with faculty mentor while facilitating USIE 88S course. Individual contract with faculty mentor required. May not be repeated. Letter grading.
THEATER 188SC.title: Individual Studies for USIE Facilitators

THEATER 189.description: Seminar, three hours. Limited to 20 students. Designed as adjunct to undergraduate lecture course. Exploration of topics in greater depth through supplemental readings, papers, or other activities and led by lecture course instructor. May be applied toward honors credit for eligible students. Honors content noted on transcript. P/NP or letter grading.
THEATER 189.title: Advanced Honors Seminars

THEATER 19.description: Seminar, one hour. Discussion of and critical thinking about topics of current intellectual importance, taught by faculty members in their areas of expertise and illuminating many paths of discovery at UCLA. P/NP grading.
THEATER 19.title: Fiat Lux Freshman Seminars

THEATER 195.description: Tutorial, eight, 16, or 24 hours. Limited to juniors/seniors. Internship at various theaters, studios, or entertainment organizations accentuating creative contributions, organization, and work of professionals in their various specialties. Students meet on regular basis with instructor and provide periodic reports of their experience. May be taken for maximum of 8 units. Individual contract with supervising faculty member required. Letter grading.
THEATER 195.title: Community or Corporate Internships in Theater, Film, and Television

THEATER 199.description: Tutorial, three hours. Limited to juniors/seniors. Supervised individual research or investigation under guidance of faculty mentor. Culminating paper or project required. May be repeated for credit. Individual contract required. P/NP or letter grading.
THEATER 199.title: Directed Research or Senior Project in Theater

THEATER 1A.description: Studio, four hours. Designed for Theater majors. Introduction to basic music theater dance technique. May be repeated once for credit. Letter grading.
THEATER 1A.title: Introduction to Dance for Music Theater

THEATER 1B.description: Studio, four hours. Designed for Theater majors. Introduction to basic music theater dance technique. May be repeated once for credit. Letter grading.
THEATER 1B.title: Introduction to Dance for Music Theater

THEATER 1C.description: Studio, four hours. Designed for Theater majors. Introduction to basic music theater dance technique. May be repeated once for credit. Letter grading.
THEATER 1C.title: Introduction to Dance for Music Theater

THEATER 2.description: Lecture, three hours; discussion, two hours. Exploration of theater in performance as revealed in productions and guest artists of UCLA International Theater Festival, with emphasis on collaborative role of theater artists and active role of audience. Students view selected productions, go back stage to discover how they are realized, and meet creative team. Letter grading.
THEATER 2.title: Theater in Performance: International Theater Festival

THEATER 20.description: Studio, four hours. Introduction to interpretation of drama through art of actor. Development of individual insights, skills, and disciplines in presentation of dramatic material to audiences. P/NP or letter grading.
THEATER 20.title: Acting Fundamentals

THEATER 205A.description: Seminar, three hours. Designed for graduate students. Analysis of major plays, commentaries, and historical materials. S/U or letter grading.
THEATER 205A.title: Background of Theatrical Art: Classical and Medieval Periods

THEATER 205B.description: Seminar, three hours. Designed for graduate students. Analysis of major plays, commentaries, and historical materials. S/U or letter grading.
THEATER 205B.title: Background of Theatrical Art: Renaissance, Baroque, and Rococo Periods

THEATER 205C.description: Seminar, three hours. Designed for graduate students. Analysis of major plays, commentaries, and historical materials. S/U or letter grading.
THEATER 205C.title: Background of Theatrical Art: Romantic, Naturalistic, and Symbolist Periods

THEATER 206.description: Seminar, four hours. Designed for graduate students. Selected topics in world theater history, drama, production, and/or architecture organized on thematic basis. May be repeated four times for credit. S/U or letter grading.
THEATER 206.title: Themes in World Theater and Drama

THEATER 208A.description: Lecture, three hours; laboratory, one hour. Designed for graduate students. Theoretical and practical aspects of dramaturge's work in contemporary theater. Letter grading.
THEATER 208A.title: Dramaturgy I

THEATER 208B.description: Lecture, three hours; laboratory, one hour. Designed for graduate students. Requisite: course 208A. Continuation of study of theory and practice of dramaturgy. Letter grading.
THEATER 208B.title: Dramaturgy II

THEATER 208C.description: Laboratory, to be arranged. Requisites: courses 208A, 208B. Demonstration of competence in practice of dramaturgy through completion of approved dramaturgical assignment. May be taken for maximum of 12 units. Letter grading.
THEATER 208C.title: Practicum in Dramaturgy

THEATER 209.description: Seminar, three hours. Designed for graduate students. Investigation of work of one theater artist from history of world theater, with special emphasis on relationship to time in which work was generated. May be repeated four times for credit. S/U or letter grading.
THEATER 209.title: Theater Authors

THEATER 21.description: Lecture, three hours. Development and practice in acting techniques. Preparation and taping of scenes for analysis. May be repeated twice for credit. Letter grading.
THEATER 21.title: Acting for Camera

THEATER 210.description: Seminar, three hours. Designed for graduate students. Investigation of selected topics in world theater, drama, production, and architecture. May be repeated four times for credit. S/U or letter grading.
THEATER 210.title: Topics in World Theater and Drama

THEATER 216A.description: Lecture, three hours; laboratory, one hour. Overview of strategies of representation from classical aesthetic theories to postmodern deconstructions of them. May be repeated once for credit. Letter grading.
THEATER 216A.title: Approaches to Representation

THEATER 216B.description: Lecture, three hours; laboratory, one hour. Overview of key methodologies, theories, and debates in historiography of theater and performance linked to plays and performances appropriate to approach. Letter grading.
THEATER 216B.title: Approaches to History

THEATER 216C.description: Lecture, three hours; laboratory, one hour. Overview of key theories, methods, debates, and performance texts of identificatory structure between audience member or scholar and theatrical or performance object. Letter grading.
THEATER 216C.title: Approaches to Identification

THEATER 220.description: Seminar, one to four hours. Limited to graduate theater students. Presentation and discussion of issues informing and affecting contemporary theater. May be repeated four times for credit. S/U grading.
THEATER 220.title: Graduate Forum

THEATER 221.description: Seminar, three hours. Investigation of performance as sustained practice in traditional disciplines such as theater, music, and dance and as lens to focus thinking about human experience in fields such as philosophy, literature, cultural anthropology, linguistics, education, and law. Emphasis on establishing interdisciplinary dialogue across many fields. Letter grading.
THEATER 221.title: Introduction to Performance Studies

THEATER 23.description: Studio, three to four hours. Introduction to reading and understanding musical notation, musical terminology, and basic to complex rhythm-reading and sight-singing in C major. Letter grading.
THEATER 23.title: Musical Literacy for Singing Actors I

THEATER 230A.description: Lecture, three hours; studio, two hours. Designed for graduate students. Analysis of strategy and dramatic structure of selected contemporary short plays leading to guided completion and critique of student-written one-act plays. Letter grading.
THEATER 230A.title: Writing for Contemporary Theater: One-Act Play

THEATER 230B.description: Lecture, three hours; studio, two hours. Designed for graduate students. Analysis of strategy and dramatic structure of selected contemporary full-length plays leading to guided completion and critique of student-written full-length play. Letter grading.
THEATER 230B.title: Writing for Contemporary Theater: Full-Length Play

THEATER 230C.description: Lecture, three hours; studio, two hours. Designed for graduate students. Exploration of structural strategies, political implications, and technical demands of selected contemporary American plays leading to guided completion and critique of student work. Letter grading.
THEATER 230C.title: Writing for Contemporary Theater: Performance and Text

THEATER 231.description: Lecture, three hours. Analysis and practice of various aspects of playwriting. Variable content selected from topics such as comedy writing, docudrama, experimental theater, writing for alternative audiences, or children's theater. May be repeated twice for credit. Letter grading.
THEATER 231.title: Special Topics in Playwriting

THEATER 232.description: Lecture, three hours. Designed for graduate students. Critical and constructive study of dramatic techniques as employed by playwrights and screenwriters in selected examples of contemporary work. May be repeated once for credit. S/U or letter grading.
THEATER 232.title: Manuscript Analysis

THEATER 242.description: Lecture or studio, four hours. Introduction to process of design for entertainment, collaborative role of designer, and realization of designs in production. May be repeated once for credit. Letter grading.
THEATER 242.title: Introduction to Design in Production

THEATER 243A.description: Studio, four hours. Advanced study and practice in scenic design for theater. Imagination as impetus for design, text analysis, metaphor, and conceptualization. Investigation of design research process, composition, and style leading to visual presentation of design. May be repeated once for credit. S/U or letter grading.
THEATER 243A.title: Scenic Design

THEATER 243B.description: Studio, four hours. Advanced study and practice in scenic design for theater. Imagination as impetus for design, text analysis, metaphor, and conceptualization. Investigation of design research process, composition, and style leading to visual presentation of design. May be repeated once for credit. S/U or letter grading.
THEATER 243B.title: Scenic Design

THEATER 243C.description: Studio, four hours. Advanced study and practice in scenic design for theater. Imagination as impetus for design, text analysis, metaphor, and conceptualization. Investigation of design research process, composition, and style leading to visual presentation of design. May be repeated once for credit. S/U or letter grading.
THEATER 243C.title: Scenic Design

THEATER 244A.description: Studio, 12 to 24 hours. Designed for graduate students. Creative participation in preparation and presentation of theatrical production. May be taken for maximum of 8 units. Letter grading.
THEATER 244A.title: Advanced Theater Production

THEATER 244B.description: Studio, 12 to 24 hours. Designed for graduate students. Creative participation in preparation and presentation of theatrical production. May be taken for maximum of 8 units. Letter grading.
THEATER 244B.title: Advanced Theater Production

THEATER 246A.description: Lecture/studio, four hours. Designed for graduate students. Study of history of costume as manifestation of cultural, social, economic, and political influences to provide historical framework for design of costumes for theater, film, and television. Historic survey and in-depth exploration of selected periods, with study of influences of diverse cultures. Letter grading.
THEATER 246A.title: History of Costume

THEATER 246B.description: Lecture/studio, four hours. Designed for graduate students. Study of history of costume as manifestation of cultural, social, economic, and political influences to provide historical framework for design of costumes for theater, film, and television. Historic survey and in-depth exploration of selected periods, with study of influences of diverse cultures. Letter grading.
THEATER 246B.title: History of Costume

THEATER 246C.description: Lecture/studio, four hours. Designed for graduate students. Study of history of costume as manifestation of cultural, social, economic, and political influences to provide historical framework for design of costumes for theater, film, and television. Historic survey and in-depth exploration of selected periods, with study of influences of diverse cultures. Letter grading.
THEATER 246C.title: History of Costume

THEATER 246D.description: Lecture, four hours. Study of history of costume as manifestation of cultural, social, economic, and political influences to provide historical framework for design of costumes for theater, film, and television. Historic survey and in-depth exploration of selected periods, with study of influences of diverse cultures. Letter grading.
THEATER 246D.title: History of Costume Design

THEATER 247.description: Studio, four hours. Designed for graduate students. Collaborative project in design, including analysis, conceptual development, and preparation of scenic, lighting, costume, or sound designs. May be repeated once for credit. Letter grading.
THEATER 247.title: Collaborative Project in Design and Production

THEATER 24A.description: Studio, three to four hours. Development of voice and speech techniques for stage. Letter grading.
THEATER 24A.title: Voice and Speech I

THEATER 24B.description: Studio, three to four hours. Development of voice and speech techniques for stage. Letter grading.
THEATER 24B.title: Voice and Speech I

THEATER 24C.description: Studio, three to four hours. Development of voice and speech techniques for stage. Letter grading.
THEATER 24C.title: Voice and Speech I

THEATER 25A.description: Studio, three to four hours. Physical awareness for actors, concentrating on warming up body, relaxation, control, stunts, gymnastics, martial arts, and use of weapons. Letter grading.
THEATER 25A.title: Movement and Combat I

THEATER 25B.description: Studio, three to four hours. Physical awareness for actors, concentrating on warming up body, relaxation, control, stunts, gymnastics, martial arts, and use of weapons. Letter grading.
THEATER 25B.title: Movement and Combat I

THEATER 25C.description: Studio, three to four hours. Physical awareness for actors, concentrating on warming up body, relaxation, control, stunts, gymnastics, martial arts, and use of weapons. Letter grading.
THEATER 25C.title: Movement and Combat I

THEATER 26.description: Studio, three hours. Study and practice in Alexander techniques as method of developing balance, poise, and coordination of body and mind. Exploration of use of rhythm to expand movement potential of actors and relevant use of visual arts and animal studies to character development and to expansion of movement potential. P/NP or letter grading.
THEATER 26.title: Alexander Techniques

THEATER 260.description: Lecture, four hours; studio, 24 hours. Designed for graduate students. Development of directorial skills of analysis, planning, staging, and criticism through medium of written preparations and directing of scenes. Letter grading.
THEATER 260.title: Directing I

THEATER 261.description: Lecture, four hours; studio, 30 hours. Designed for graduate students. Problems in direction of post-realist plays through interpretation and laboratory scene work. Letter grading.
THEATER 261.title: Directing Post-Realist Drama

THEATER 263.description: Discussion, one hour; studio, 12 to 30 hours. Designed for graduate students. Direction of dramatic work, with discussion and critique of work in progress. May be repeated for maximum of 20 units. Letter grading.
THEATER 263.title: Production Project in Direction for Stage

THEATER 264.description: Lecture, four hours; studio, 30 hours. Designed for graduate students. Problems in interpretation and direction of historical or classical drama through medium of laboratory scene work. May be repeated once for credit. Letter grading.
THEATER 264.title: Directing Classical and Historical Drama

THEATER 265.description: Lecture, four hours. Examination of modern theories of production from emergence of director in 19th century to present. Investigation of different responses to problems of creating vital theatric event in context of ongoing evolution of theater as art form. Examination of contribution of significant directors and movements; relation between theater and other forms of representation. Letter grading.
THEATER 265.title: Modern Theories of Production

THEATER 266.description: Lecture, four hours. Examination of process of conceptualization in dramatic production; centrality of theatric conceptualization in interpretation of dramatic text; exploration of range of possibilities inherent in different theatrical spaces and options in design components. Consideration of visual arts and music as sources of stimulus for theatrical conceptualization, with focus on collaborative aspect of theatrical production. Letter grading.
THEATER 266.title: Theatrical Conceptualization

THEATER 27.description: Studio, three to four hours. Exploration of many aspects of comedy using American vaudeville traditions, acts, and performers as historical base to experience importance of rhythm, timing, delivery, speech, and body language in all styles of comedy, to find value of improvisation/imagination as well as innovative writing skills in all comic forms, to discover how comedy draws from so many art forms, including music/songs, dance, storytelling, clowning, magic, design, and tumbling/stunts, and to build overall confidence/ease in comic performance skills. P/NP or letter grading.
THEATER 27.title: From Vaudeville to Standup Comedy

THEATER 272.description: Studio, three to eight hours. Exploration and laboratory experience in one or more various aspects of production and postproduction practice for entertainment media, including theater, film, video, and digital media. May be repeated for maximum of 24 units. Letter grading.
THEATER 272.title: Production Practice in Theater, Film, Video, and Digital Media

THEATER 28A.description: Studio, three to six hours. Study of beginning acting technique, scene study, and development of voice and movement skills. May be repeated for maximum of 12 units. Letter grading.
THEATER 28A.title: Acting, Voice, and Movement Workshop I

THEATER 28B.description: Studio, three to six hours. Study of beginning acting technique, scene study, and development of voice and movement skills. May be repeated for maximum of 12 units. Letter grading.
THEATER 28B.title: Acting, Voice, and Movement Workshop I

THEATER 28C.description: Studio, three to six hours. Study of beginning acting technique, scene study, and development of voice and movement skills. May be repeated for maximum of 12 units. Letter grading.
THEATER 28C.title: Acting, Voice, and Movement Workshop I

THEATER 28D.description: Studio, three to six hours. Study of beginning acting technique, scene study, and development of voice and movement skills. May be repeated for maximum of 12 units. Letter grading.
THEATER 28D.title: Acting, Voice, and Movement Workshop I

THEATER 28E.description: Studio, six hours. Study of beginning acting technique, scene study, and development of voice and movement skills. May be repeated for maximum of 12 units. Letter grading.
THEATER 28E.title: Acting, Voice, and Movement Workshop I

THEATER 28F.description: Studio, six hours. Study of beginning acting technique, scene study, and development of voice and movement skills. May be repeated for maximum of 12 units. Letter grading.
THEATER 28F.title: Acting, Voice, and Movement Workshop I

THEATER 298A.description: Lecture/discussion, two or four hours. Designed for graduate students. Seminar study of problems in theater arts, organized on topic basis. May be repeated once for credit. S/U or letter grading.
THEATER 298A.title: Special Studies in Theater Arts

THEATER 298B.description: Lecture/discussion, two or four hours. Designed for graduate students. Seminar study of problems in theater arts, organized on topic basis. May be repeated once for credit. S/U or letter grading.
THEATER 298B.title: Special Studies in Theater Arts

THEATER 30.description: Studio, three hours. Intended for Theater minors and other nonmajors. Exploration and development of creative writing skills for one or more of various forms of entertainment media. May be repeated once. Letter grading.
THEATER 30.title: Dramatic Writing

THEATER 34A.description: Studio, five hours. Development of dance and movement techniques for musical theater. Letter grading.
THEATER 34A.title: Dance for Musical Theater I

THEATER 34B.description: Studio, five hours. Development of dance and movement techniques for musical theater. Letter grading.
THEATER 34B.title: Dance for Musical Theater I

THEATER 34C.description: Studio, five hours. Development of dance and movement techniques for musical theater. Letter grading.
THEATER 34C.title: Dance for Musical Theater I

THEATER 35A.description: Studio, four to five hours. Exploration of musical literacy and development of singing techniques for musical theater. Basic voice training to explore how voice works, learn to maintain appropriate and consistent voice, and learn to preserve voice health. How to build stamina and range. Letter grading.
THEATER 35A.title: Singing for Musical Theater I

THEATER 35B.description: Studio, four to five hours. Exploration of musical literacy and development of singing techniques for musical theater. Basic voice training to explore how voice works, learn to maintain appropriate and consistent voice, and learn to preserve voice health. How to build stamina and range. Letter grading.
THEATER 35B.title: Singing for Musical Theater I

THEATER 35C.description: Studio, four to five hours. Exploration of musical literacy and development of singing techniques for musical theater. Basic voice training to explore how voice works, learn to maintain appropriate and consistent voice, and learn to preserve voice health. How to build stamina and range. Letter grading.
THEATER 35C.title: Singing for Musical Theater I

THEATER 375.description: Seminar, to be arranged. Preparation: apprentice personnel employment as teaching assistant, associate, or fellow. Teaching apprenticeship under active guidance and supervision of regular faculty member responsible for curriculum and instruction at UCLA. May be repeated for credit. S/U grading.
THEATER 375.title: Teaching Apprentice Practicum

THEATER 4.description: Lecture, three hours; discussion, two hours. Readings in English. Exploration of Israel and Palestine through artistic, cultural, and political modes of analysis. Examination of selected works of literature, theater, and film dramatic by Israeli, Palestinian, and Western artists, looking beyond facile cultural clichés to deeper insights. Letter grading.
THEATER 4.title: Israel and Palestine in Literature and Media

THEATER 420A.description: Studio, six to 18 hours. Development of internal technique, beginning with autodrama that is dramatization of one's personal history. Scene work follows, with emphasis on off-stage preparations, improvisations capturing circumstances, life of character, and intentions of scene. Letter grading.
THEATER 420A.title: Advanced Acting I

THEATER 420B.description: Studio, six to 18 hours. Scene work, usually from 20 to 30 minutes in length. Continuation of work on off-stage preparation, with further development of how actor goes about doing research and fieldwork on character being played. Letter grading.
THEATER 420B.title: Advanced Acting I

THEATER 420C.description: Studio, six to 18 hours. Development of external technique through comedy and of skits, improvisation, physical humor, delivery of lines, rhythm, timing, and public cabaret. Fusion of internal; use of action and objective with external. Letter grading.
THEATER 420C.title: Advanced Acting I

THEATER 421A.description: Studio/laboratory, six to 18 hours. Extending idea of autobiography and using it as art. Actor as performance artist. Playing characters quite removed from oneself. Using language. Using Shakespeare and oneself to play him. Letter grading.
THEATER 421A.title: Advanced Acting II

THEATER 421B.description: Studio/laboratory, six to 18 hours. Continued character behavior study through language and movement. Further work on actions, objectives, and researching role. Letter grading.
THEATER 421B.title: Advanced Acting II

THEATER 421C.description: Studio/laboratory, six to 18 hours. Comedy workshop. Exploration of craft of comedy and development of cabaret pieces. Letter grading.
THEATER 421C.title: Advanced Acting II

THEATER 422.description: Studio/laboratory, eight to 12 hours. Intensive performance experience. May be repeated for maximum of 24 units. Letter grading.
THEATER 422.title: Advanced Acting for Theater, Film, and Television

THEATER 423.description: Studio, three hours. Development and practice in performance techniques for film and television. Exploration of language used by actors and directors in film and television production and subtle differences between acting for stage and camera. Working in multicamera studio environment, students prepare and tape scenes for analysis. May be repeated twice for credit. Letter grading.
THEATER 423.title: Advanced Acting for Camera

THEATER 424A.description: Studio/laboratory, three to six hours. Development of voice and speech techniques for stage, including those of relaxation, breathing, resonance, and development of speaking voice. Speech training uses International Phonetic Alphabet to train students in standard American speech. Text work in poetry and prose. Letter grading.
THEATER 424A.title: Advanced Voice and Speech I

THEATER 424B.description: Studio, three hours. Requisite: course 424A. Builds on course 424A. Introduction of vowel diphthongs and triphthongs; development of forward sound, including consistent thought energy. Exercises to develop, and text to implement forward sound, including consistent thought energy. Text and warm-up exercises also covered. Letter grading.
THEATER 424B.title: Vowels and Voice Placement (Effective Spring 2018 )

THEATER 424C.description: Studio, three hours. Requisite: course 424A. Physical explorations and techniques for breath sourcing and increasing awareness of voice in action. Sensory awareness work, Linklater and Barry technqisues, and Knight-Thompson model may also be explored. Letter grading.
THEATER 424C.title: Voice in Action (Effective Spring 2018 )

THEATER 424D.description: Studio/laboratory, three to six hours. Advanced voice problems. Extension of first-year work, with increased demands on voice. Range, resonance, and breathing capacity extension. Articulation and phonetic alphabet. Text work in classical verse. Letter grading.
THEATER 424D.title: Advanced Voice and Speech II

THEATER 424E.description: Studio/laboratory, three to six hours. Advanced voice problems. Extension of first-year work, with increased demands on voice. Range, resonance, and breathing capacity extension. Articulation and phonetic alphabet. Text work in classical verse. Letter grading.
THEATER 424E.title: Advanced Voice and Speech II

THEATER 424F.description: Studio/laboratory, three to six hours. Advanced voice problems. Extension of first-year work, with increased demands on voice. Range, resonance, and breathing capacity extension. Articulation and phonetic alphabet. Text work in classical verse. Letter grading.
THEATER 424F.title: Advanced Voice and Speech II

THEATER 424G.description: Studio, three to six hours. Extension of second-year work, with increased demands on voice/speech, range, resonance, and breathing capacity extension. Application of ear training and International Phonetic Alphabet to creation of dialect and accents, as well as systematic approach to creating dialect charts. Letter grading.
THEATER 424G.title: Advanced Voice and Speech III

THEATER 424H.description: Studio, three to six hours. Extension of second-year work, with increased demands on voice/speech, range, resonance, and breathing capacity extension. Application of ear training and International Phonetic Alphabet to creation of dialect and accents, as well as systematic approach to creating dialect charts. Letter grading.
THEATER 424H.title: Advanced Voice and Speech III

THEATER 424I.description: Studio, three to six hours. Extension of second-year work, with increased demands on voice/speech, range, resonance, and breathing capacity extension. Application of ear training and International Phonetic Alphabet to creation of dialect and accents, as well as systematic approach to creating dialect charts. Letter grading.
THEATER 424I.title: Advanced Voice and Speech III

THEATER 425A.description: Studio/laboratory, three to six hours. Discovery of body's unique language through exercises designed to explore and free total instrument. Development of flexible actor with range, expression, and confidence physically. May be repeated for maximum of 12 units. Letter grading.
THEATER 425A.title: Advanced Movement I

THEATER 425B.description: Studio/laboratory, three to six hours. Discovery of body's unique language through exercises designed to explore and free total instrument. Development of flexible actor with range, expression, and confidence physically. Awakening of imagination while exploring worlds of ritual, animal, conceptual, and modern dance movements. Letter grading.
THEATER 425B.title: Advanced Movement I

THEATER 425C.description: Studio/laboratory, three to six hours. Discovery of body's unique language through exercises designed to explore and free total instrument. Development of flexible actor with range, expression, and confidence physically. Awakening of imagination while exploring worlds of ritual, animal, conceptual, and modern dance movements. Letter grading.
THEATER 425C.title: Advanced Movement I

THEATER 425D.description: Studio/laboratory, three to six hours. Presentation of more complete picture of stage movement and its relationship to theater, music, and dance. Advancement of physical training of individual actors to their maximum potential. Experience in techniques and discovery of origins of variety of acrobatic and dance disciplines, including ballet, ballroom, period dance, and circus techniques. Letter grading.
THEATER 425D.title: Advanced Movement II

THEATER 425E.description: Studio/laboratory, three to six hours. Presentation of more complete picture of stage movement and its relationship to theater, music, and dance. Advancement of physical training of individual actors to their maximum potential. Experience in techniques and discovery of origins of variety of acrobatic and dance disciplines, including ballet, ballroom, period dance, and circus techniques. Letter grading.
THEATER 425E.title: Advanced Movement II
